subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 31st August (vide page 2253), on motion by Senator Pearce -

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Lt.-Colonel Sir ALBERTGOULD (New South Wales) [12.56]. - A good many years have elapsed since we first considered the subject Of navigation. In 1904 a Bill was introduced by Senator Drake, who at that time represented the Government in the Senate. He gave us a long history of navigation as affecting the Old Country and Other parts of the world. Every one realizes that the greatness of England depends in no small degree upon her navigation policy. The navigation laws of other countries have also had much to do with their progress. At one time the United States of America enjoyed a large portion of the carrying trade of the world. But eventually she lost much of that trade, and gradually reached the position which she occupies to-day,. Her oversea trade is now email in comparison with what it was years ago. We must legislate in the light of history, and must have close regard to what has happened in other countries. We are now asked to pass a Bill which may or may not land us in difficulties, and which may or may not be in accordance with the powers conferred upon us by our Constitution.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I have alluded to the importance of this measure from many points of view, but I realize that it is one which can be better dealt with in Committee. There are, however, some matters connected with it which are worthy of attention on the second reading. I have mentioned that, so far as this Parliament is concerned, there is a history attached to this measure. After the introduction of the first measure of the kind in the early days of Federation, it was found desirable that it should be referred to a Royal Commission for' inquiry and report. Subsequently a Navigation Conference was held in .the Old Country, and the way in which the matter of navigation should be dealt with by British Possessions was considered. It had always to be borne in mind that there were many limitations upon the powers of the State Parliaments to legislate on the subject of navigation. The provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act are applicable to the whole of the British Empire, and there is a limitation upon the extent to which the Parliament of any British Possession may enact alterations of that law. I am aware that at one time - and there is a minute by Mr. Garran to that effect - we were advised that the Commonwealth Parliament has almost plenary powers to deal with the question. It was stated by the legal advisers of the Commonwealth Government that the powers conferred on the Commonwealth Parliament under the Constitution exceeded those previously enjoyed by the State Parliaments, and that it was desirable that we should exercise those powers to the full if, in the interests of the Commonwealth, and of navigation and shipping generally in these waters, that appeared to be necessary. lt will be seen, however, by a reference to section 5 of the Constitution, that our powers in this matter are limited to a considerable extent. The section provides, amongst other things, that- the laws of the Commonwealth shall be in force on all British ships, the Queen's ships of war excepted, whose first port of clearance and whose port of destination are in the Commonwealth.

subdebate.1.para: One would have assumed from that that our powers extended merely to vessels engaged in what is called the coasting trade. But I think it was contended that our powers were more extended under sections 51 and 98 of the Constitution. Section 98 provides that -

quote.para: The power of the Parliament to make laws with respect to trade and commerce extends to navigation and shipping, and to railways the property of any State.

subdebate.1.para: The question was submitted to the Imperial authorities, and a reply to the following effect was received in a despatch from the Secretary of State for the Colonies, dated September, 1908 -

quote.para: His Majesty's Government regret that they are unable to agree with your Ministers as to the power of legislation in regard to navigation, which has been conferred upon the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia by the Imperial Act of 1900. . . . His Majesty's Government obtained an opinion from the then Law Officers of the Crown and another distinguished constitutional lawyer, as to the powers of legislation in matters of navigation . conferred upon the Commonwealth Parliament. They are advised that the Parliament has only such powers of legislation so as to override the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894, as are given by sections 735 and 736 of that Act, and that the effect of section 51 (1) and section 98 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth is merely to confer upon the Commonwealth Parliament a power of legislation on navigation matters paramount to that of the State Parliaments, but that these sections do not in any way extend the legislative power of the Commonwealth beyond the powers previously exercised by the State Legislatures. . . His Majesty's Government are advised that it is not open to the Commonwealth Parliament to enact any legislation which is repugnant to any provisions of the Imperial Shipping Acts which extend to the whole of His Majesty's Dominions.

subdebate.1.para: It is just as well that I should refer to the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act, which are applicable to every part of the British Empire, to see what our powers in the matter are, and to what extent they are limited. I make these observations, because I think there has been a tendency on the part of the Government to go beyond the powers conferred upon the Commonwealth, in view of the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894. Section 735 of that Act makes provision that -

quote.para: The Legislature of any British Possession may by an Act or ordinance, confirmed by Her Majesty in Council, repeal, wholly or in part, any provisions of this Act (other than those of the third part thereof which relate to immigrant ships) relating to ships registered in that Possession; but any such Act or ordinance shall not take effect until the approval of Her Majesty has been proclaimed in the Possession.

subdebate.1.para: From that it would appear that we have power to make alterations in the provisions of the Imperial Act to apply only to ships registered in the Commonwealth. That section deals with one class of ships, which may be oversea ships, and not confined merely to the coasting trade. In the following section - section 736 - provision is . made that -

quote.para: The Legislature of a British Possession may, by any Act or ordinance, regulate the coasting trades of that British Possession, subject in every case to the following conditions.

subdebate.1.para: The conditions are enumerated, and the section continues -

quote.para: The Act or ordinance shall treat all British ships (including the ships of any other British Possession) in exactly the same manner as ships of the British Possession in which it is made.

Where by treaty made before the passing of the Merchant Shipping (Colonial) Act r86g (that is to say, before the 13th day of May, 1869) Her Majesty has agreed to grant to any ships of any foreign State any rights or privileges in respect of the coasting trade of any British Possession, those rights and privileges shall be enjoyed by those ships for so long as Her Ma- jesty has already agreed or may hereafter agree to grant the same, anything in the Act or ordinance to the contrary notwithstanding.

subdebate.1.para: Honorable senators will realize from this that our powers are considerably limited. However, desirous we may be of taking action beyond our powers, any legislation we pass on the subject can have no validity until it has received the Imperial assent, and I doubt very much how far that would assist us, if the legislation went beyond our powers to contravene the provisions of the Merchant Shipping Act. I believe that an attempt was made by a member of this Parliament to ascertain what treaties there were in existence which would be likely to affect our legislation in respect of navigation and shipping. We have not yet heard what treaties are in existence, and we may, therefore, to a certain extent, be legislating in the dark in dealing with this measure. We may legislate in such a way as to infringe the provisions of treaties made by the Imperial authorities with foreign powers, giving reciprocal rights and privileges in the matter of navigation and shipping. It will be a very serious mistake for us to attempt to deal with foreign ships in such a way as perhaps to lead the nations to which they belong to consider that they were not being fairly dealt with. Retaliation in such a matter might be of little concern to the Commonwealth, but it might be of very great importance to the merchant shipping of Great Britain. It would be impossible for Great Britain to plead that the law was passed by one of her Dependencies, as the foreign Power concerned would contend that it was the duty of Great Britain to take cognisance of laws passed in any of her Possessions, and that it was her duty to take steps to protect them against any interference with rights conceded to them in consideration of rights conceded to Great Britain.

talk.start.para: - Does the honorable senator not think that it would be the other way about?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - In some cases it would, no doubt. The Bill of 1904 in this direction went considerably beyond what is now proposed. This was no doubt justified by the belief held at the time that our powers in dealing with the subject of navigation and shipping were much greater than they now appear to be. We have had Conferences since then, and I recognise at once that many of the objectionable fea- lures of the Navigation Bill originally introduced have been eliminated from the measure now before us. Within our sphere of legislation we are very properly anxious to provide good accommodation and reasonable conditions for all seamen employed on vessels engaged in our coasting trade or registered in Australia. But in doing so we should be careful not to interfere with the general interests of the community. Many of our farmers and settlers in the coastal districts are entirely dependent for the carriage of their produce to ports of distribution and sale upon the services of coasting vessels. In our legislation affecting vessels engaged in the coasting trade we should bear this in mind, and while providing good conditions for seamen, we should not enact provisions which would have the effect of unnecessarily and unduly increasing freight of produce along our coast to the various distributing centres. There are provisions in this Bill which would impose restrictions upon the owners of vessels engaged in the coasting trade which might materially reduce the carrying capacity of their ships, and so result in higher freights. Intimately connected with this matter is the question of accommodation, and it is just as well that honorable senators should note the way in which the quantity of space which it is proposed to allocate to each seaman has grown since this Bill was originally introduced. In 1904, it was proposed that we should follow the lines laid down in the Merchant Shipping Act of 1894, which allowed 72 cubic feet of space to each sailor.
- Which was a most absurd proposal.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - In 1906, the Merchant Shipping Act was amended, and in the amending Act, the space provided for each seaman was increased from 72 cubic feet to 120 cubic feet. But in clause 137 of this Bill, it is proposed that each seaman shall have a space of not less than 140 cubic feet. That clause reads -

item.para: Every space in a ship registered in Australia or engaged in the coasting trade, which is appropriated to the berthing accommodation of seamen or apprentices, shall -

item.label: (a)
item.para: have for each seaman or apprentice a space of not less than one hundred and forty cubic feet and of not less than eighteen superficial feet measured on the deck or floor of that place and of not less than Jive feet measured between bunks clear of all encumbrances at the forward or narrow end.

subdebate.1.para: Upon referring to the report of the Navigation Commission of 1904. I find that of the witnesses examined in respect of this matter, only three favoured the allocation of 140 cubic feet to each seaman, eleven favored 120 cubic feet, an equal number advocated 100 cubic feet, and six thought that 72 cubic feet would be sufficient. I assume that honorable senators will scarcely regard 72 cubic feet as being sufficient, nor will they be inclined to accept 100 cubic feet. But in this Bill, it is proposed to increase the accommodation of each sailor to 140 cubic feet. Whilst that may not be too much space to provide on the larger class of vessels, I think it is too much in the case of vessels of limited size, which are engaged in our - coastal trade, and which are often required to enter bar-bound harbors in order to carry on the trade of the country. This is a matter which has been brought under my notice by some of the coastal shipping people themselves. Under the Merchant Shipping Act of 1906, an exemption is granted to ships of less than 300 tons burden in respect of the quantity of space to be allocated to each seaman. It is further provided that the area occupied by the mess, bath, and washing rooms may be deducted from that space, but that not less than 72 cubic feet and 12 superficial feet shall be provided for each seaman or apprentice. Thus, while reserving thefull quantity of space, namely, 120 cubic feet upon smaller vessels, it is nevertheless possible for portion of that space to be occupied by the mess, bath, and washing rooms, I think it would be well for us to consider whether, in view of the number of small vessels which are engaged in our coastal trade, we should not be acting wisely if we framed a somewhat similar provision.

talk.start.para: - What does it mean - half a ton of cargo per voyage?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I have no desire to deprive the men who are engaged in our coastal trade of any comfort which we can reasonably confer upon them. I realize to the full that it is time we, as a nation, did all that we can to make seafaring life attractive to the youth of Australia. I recognise, too, that it would be far better for us to have our ships manned solely by British subjects. Under existing circumstances, however, that is not possible. But we should certainly do all that we can to make a seafaring life one which will be not lightly set aside. The position of Great

subdebate.1.para: Britain to-day is entirely dependent on her sea power, which, in turn, is dependent upon the men who accept service in her ships of war. The mercantile marine is one of the best schools in which our young men may become qualified to enter the navy. Our navy should be placed in the position of being able to obtain seamen without difficulty, because so surely as the time of stress and trouble arrives, so surely must that navy be materially increased, not only in ships, but also in men.

talk.start.para: - At the present time the majority of the men who are engaged in our mercantile marine are foreigners.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I am under the impression that a majority of them are not foreigners, though I admit that there is a considerable proportion of foreigners amongst them. I wish also to point out to Ministers that if we are able to establish schools of instruction in which youths may be educated for a seafaring life, they will prove a valuable adjunct to our mercantile marine. In some of the States, such schools exist, but they have been established primarily for the purpose of educating the waifs and strays of the community, so as to fit them to earn an honest livelihood.
- Very few of the youths educated in those schools ever go to sea.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - In agreat country like Australia, we know that shore life presents more attractions to our young men than does a seafaring life. Consequently, it behoves us, as far as possible, to make a seafaring life attractive, in order that we may have men upon whom we can fall back should we ever require their services. The Commonwealth is now about to embark upon a naval career. It is providing itself with ships of war, all of which we hope to see manned by Australians. Unfortunately, we shall be compelled at first to man them with a large number of men from the Old Country. But, ultimately, we hope that they will be manned by Australians. If Australia means to defend herself against aggression, she will, in the not distant future, have to materially increase the number of warships which she now has in course of construction. I regard those vessels merely as a commencement in the matter of our naval defence, if this continent is to be maintained in its integrity. At the same time, we must be prepared to meet the requirements of our people upon land, and to prevent them from incurring increased expenditure in the carriage of their goods to the various distributing centres. Clause 208 of the Bill provides -

item.para: All steam-ships registered in Australia or engaged in the coastal trade shall, if required by the regulations, be divided by transverse water-tight partitions in the prescribed manner, and have water-tight false bottoms.

subdebate.1.para: The marginal note states that this provision has been taken from the New South Wales Act of 1901, and the New Zealand Act of 1903. I have referred to both those Statutes, and I find that the provision requiring vessels to have watertight false bottoms is not contained in either.

talk.start.para: - It is contained in Lloyd's regulations.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - That may be so. But we have to recollect that if it were really necessary to legislate on this particular matter, it would have been dealt with ere now, if not by the Old Country, at any rate by some of the Australian States. Some honorable senators have declared that the Navigation Act of New Zealand represents a considerable advance upon the navigation laws operative in other dependencies. If the Dominion has found it unnecessary to embody a provision of this kind in its Navigation Act, we ought to pause before we incorporate it in this Bill. We must recollect that whilst water-tight false bottoms undoubtedly add to the safety of a vessel, there are - especially on the coast of New South Wales - so many bar-bound harbors that every inch by which the cargocarrying capacity of our small vessels is reduced is a matter of great importance.
- That provision will benefit the class of vessels to which the honorable senator refers, because it will give them more buoyancy.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I doubt the accuracy of the honorable senator's statement. If we sacrifice space, however small, upon the whole of the bottom of a ship, we must necessarily decrease her carrying capacity. To enter very many of our harbors, vessels have to cross bars upon which there is not more than 5, 6, or 7 feet of water, and it is no uncommon thing to find them bar-bound for days. When we come to deal with this clause, therefore, we shall be wise if we eliminate that provision unless it be considered desirable to retain it in the case of deep-sea ships. Of course, we all realize that the lives of our seamen are just as precious as are the lives of sea-going passengers, and that the same amount of consideration should be extended to them. But my remarks apply, I think, with considerable force to the vessels engaged in our coastal trade. It has been pointed out that the manning scale provided for in the Bill is somewhat larger than is necessary. That, however, is a matter with which we can deal in Committee. I come now to the question of the survey of steam-ships. In this Bill, it is proposed that ships, after they are five years old, shall be surveyed every six months. I recollect that some time ago the New South Wales Parliament enacted that ships should be surveyed every six months. At that time there were a great many representations made that the adjoining States had not made a similar provision. I think that the case of Victoria was quoted, which considered that a survey once a year was sufficient, and it was pointed out that the probability was that vessels, instead of being registered in New South Wales, would be registered in Victoria. From the correspondence with the Board of Trade we find that considerable exception was taken to the necessity of making a provision of this character, at any rate as regards ships not registered in Australia, or ships not engaged in the coasting trade. It was urged that it would entail delay and expense unnecessarily. It was described, I think, in the correspondence as an unnecessary provision, because the authorities were already invested with power to require a survey to be made of any ship which they had reason to believe was not safe.
- In Victoria the Marine Board stopped one vessel from leaving port and had to pay damages for doing so.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I presume that the stoppage of the ship was made without justification?
- No.
- Does the honorable senator advocate the abolition of that power ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - No, he is advocating that these ships should be surveyed every six months.
- They should not be exempted from survey, as under the British law.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator has taken no exception to a survey being allowed to take place once a year. I think that that has been the provision in all the States, except New South Wales, until the alteration was made.
- No, in South Australia, Queensland, and Western Australia the law provides for a survey being made every six months.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - In view of the correspondence which has taken place, I submit that a survey once a year would be found to be quite sufficient if there were adequate provision to enable the marine authorities, whenever they had reasonable ground for so doing, to cause a ship to be surveyed before leaving port. I think that that would meet the whole of the requirements.
- What the Board of Trade objects to is thatwe want a survey to be made every twelve months.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I think that the honorable senator will admit that, according to the correspondence, the Board of Trade were practically prepared to accede to the proposal that a survey should be made once a year.
- Not in the case of British ships.

- When representations were made so determinedly as to the necessity of having ships after they were five years old surveyed every six months, the Board of Trade suggested that there should be a provision made in our Bill to exempt ships which were not registered here, or which were not engaged in our coasting trade. I do not know but that the Board of Trade is in an impregnable position in taking up that attitude, seeing that our powers are so limited. The provision might cause retaliation in connexion with nations other than Great Britain, and it might also be a hindrance to our getting the Royal Assent, because it appears to me that, to a certain extent, we have, in this legislation, to walk warily. We know that at one time the Home authorities were not desirous of interfering with the trend of our legislation, however undesirable they might consider it. With regard to our general legislation they realize that we are better qualified to judge of many matters which affect us than are those who live many thousands of miles from our shores. On the question of manning we might very well pay heed to their suggestions. Passing from that I come to the question of the coasting trade. The Bill which was introduced here in 1904 contained the following provision, which I think was practically adopted in a later measure -

quote.para: A ship shall be deemed to engage in the coasting trade if she takes on board passengers or cargo at any port in Australia to be carried to, ' and landed or delivered at, any other port in Australia.

subdebate.1.para: The next clause read -

quote.para: Until the railways of the State of Western Australia are connected with the railways of the State of South Australia, the carrying of passengers between Western Australia and South Australia by any British ship ordinarily carrying mails to or from the Commonwealth shall not be deemed engaging in the coasting trade.

subdebate.1.para: That provision was followed up later with the idea that persons who wish to travel between Western Australia and the southern or eastern coast should have a large choice of ships to travel in. But I understand that the provision was dropped when it was pointed out that it was doubtful whether it came within our legislative powers under the. Constitution. I refer to section 99, which reads -

quote.para: The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade, commerce, or revenue, give preference to one State, or any part thereof, over another State, or any part thereof.

subdebate.1.para: It did appear - and I believe it was recognised that it did appear - that a provision of that character would contravene the section, because it would give a preference in one State over other States in connexion with a matter of trade, or commerce, or navigation. It must be evident that if we gave to the residents of Western Australia an opportunity to travel by a particular class of ships which we denied to another portion of the Commonwealth the law would, undoubtedly, be more favorable to that State than to other States. Indeed, it might be an inducement to persons to reside in a State which was provided with special opportunities for travelling to and fro. It would be a great convenience in regard to ordinary trade and commerce to be in a State that enjoyed advantages which were denied to other States. This, it has always appeared to me, is a difficult question for a Government to deal with, if they want to make every ship which carries passengers on our coast conform to the provisions of an Act applicable to ships registered in our own ports. What are the Government trying to do at present? By a clause which corresponds with the one I quoted they are taking to themselves power to do practically the same thing, hut in a different way.

talk.start.para: - By proclamation.
- However it may be done, Western Australia will have the benefit of cheap labour, whereas the other States will not.
- Make it all white.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The difficulty is that you cannot make the world white. Clause 283 of this Bill reads -

quote.para: A ship shall be deemed to engage in the coasting trade if she takes on board 'passengers or cargo at any port in Australia, or any territory under the authority of the Commonwealth, to be carried to, and landed or delivered at, any other port in Australia or in any such territory :

subdebate.1.para: Unquestionably no oversea ships would be in a position to carry passengers from Western Australia to Adelaide, or Melbourne, or Sydney.

talk.start.para: - Where does the Bill mention Western Australia?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I shall come to that directly.
- It is taking the honorable senator a long time to do so. Does the present Bill mention Western Australia ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It does not specifically mention Western Australia, but as clause 283 stands it will be impossible for any ships belonging to the Peninsular and Oriental line, or to the Orient line, or to any of the other oversea lines, to carry passengers beyond Perth who desire to go to Adelaide, or Melbourne, or Sydney, unless the ships are prepared to submit to the whole of the restrictions and requirements contained in the provision. Surely honorable senators cannot expect ships which are registered at the other end of the world, and carry cargo all over the world, to place themselves under specific restrictions so as to enable them to carry an infinitesimal number of passengers from one part of Australia to another ! Although Western Australia has not been specifically mentioned in the clause the probability is that it would be the State which would receive an advantage from the proposal of the Government. The clause contains this proviso -

quote.para: Provided that the carrying of passengers who hold through tickets to or from a port beyond Australia, or of cargo consigned on a through bill of lading to or from a port beyond Australia, or of mails, shall not be deemed engaging in the coasting trade:

subdebate.1.para: Whilst it is well to make that clear and specific in our law, still I do not see how we can interfere with the carriage of passengers in that way. Take the case of a ship which carries passengers from London to Sydney, and has to call in at Perth, Adelaide, and Melbourne. That ship would be precluded from carrying her passengers for the whole distance for which they were booked, and she would have to disembark them at Perth and put them on board another vessel.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator misunderstands the proviso. It refers 10 passengers who break their passage. They can be taken on afterwards.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It would undoubtedly cover that, too.
- That is what it is meant for.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The clause contains this further proviso -

quote.para: Provided further that the Governor-General may by order declare that the carrying of passengers between specified ports in Australia, by British ships, shall not be deemed engaging in the coasting trade.

subdebate.1.para: The objection to this provision is that it is against the Constitution, in that it empowers the Governor-General to declare that as between certain States there shall be privileges and advantages given which shall not exist as between other States. In other words, the Governor-General could issue a proclamation which would enable British ships to carry passengers from Perth to Adelaide without being deemed to be engaged in the coasting trade. I am glad to see that there is no .attempt to distinguish between the different lines, so long as the ships are British.

talk.start.para: - But there might be an attempt made under the proclamation.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - No, because the power of the Governor-General is restricted to British ships.
- They could distinguish between one British line and another.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I do not think that under this measure the Governor-General would have power to discriminate in the case of British ships which were going between given ports. British ships, trading between Perth and Adelaide, might get an exemption between those two ports, but British ships which called first at Adelaide and then, at Melbourne would not receive a similar concession. That might happen. The

subdebate.1.para: Government are still attempting to deal with the matter similarly to the way in which it was dealt with in the Bill of 1904. My contention is that the moment the GovernorGeneral issued a proclamation that all British ships which called at Perth and carried passengers to Adelaide, or Melbourne, or Sydney, should not be deemed to be engaged in the coasting trade, it would give a specific advantage to two particular States or ports and deny it to ships carrying passengers from, say, Sydney to Hobart Vessels coming from England and calling at Hobart might also be precluded from carrying passengers. By this means, there would be discrimination, directly in violation of section 99 of the Constitution, which absolutely provides that we shall not do anything of the kind. The clause also provides for preference to one State over all the other States.

talk.start.para: - If the clause were unconstitutional, it would have no effect.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - But surely the honorable senator can see that if we deliberately legislate against the Constitution we shall produce a cause of dissatisfaction amongst the people who are concerned. We shall also cause the people engaged in the shipping trade to wonder what kind of proceedings they will have to take in order to obtain their rights. I maintain that this is not a reasonable provision to insert. I do not object to the people of Western Australia availing themselves of the opportunity of travelling in the most convenient and comfortable way possible; but I think the clause should be worded so as to show that it is intended to allow passengers to be carried between ports in Australia as long as they travel by British ships. We have lately entered into a contract with the Orient Steam Navigation Company by which we compel them to make calls at certain ports. They have, first of all, to call at Fremantle; then successively at Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, and Brisbane; so that the itinerary to which they are bound necessitates their making a considerable voyage along our coasts. As a matter of fact, they do not carry cargo between those ports. Their main traffic is confined to passengers. But I assume that when a contract is entered into, and ships are required to call at certain ports, they should have facilities for picking up a certain class of passenger traffic to assist them in reducing the expenses that they incur in carrying out their itinerary. These vessels always charge higher fares than do the ships regularly trading on our own coast. It may be said that they are not bound to charge higher fares, but still it has been their practice to do so. While I admit that our coasting vessels are put to greater expense because of the different conditions in Australia from those prevailing in other parts of the world - that is to say, greater expenses for wages, for manning, and for accommodation - it must also be borne in mind that our own local marine masters are exempt from pilotage, whilst no exemption is granted to the commanders of oversea vessels.
- Nor. is exemption granted to Australian-registered ships going foreign.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - That, at any rate, is one saving made by our local marine. Then, again, foreign-going ships have to pay Suez Canal dues, which are very heavy ; and there are other expenses to which they are put that are not incurred by the vessels engaged in our coasting trade. So that there is really something to be said on the other side in regard to expenses. Owing to the enterprise and energy of the Australian shipping companies, we now have some magnificent vessels on our coast j if not equal to the latest type of foreign-going ships, they are, at any rate, equal, and in many instances superior, to vessels that a few years ago we considered to be first class. After all, the people of the Commonwealth ought to have an opportunity of taking advantage of the visit of these oversea ships for the purpose of travelling between Australian ports. I would not ask that they should be allowed to carry cargo along our coasts. There are many good reasons why they should not be permitted to do so. But it is only reasonable to allow them to carry passengers. The only restriction imposed should be that ships engaged in the passenger trade should be British ships. In case it should be argued that it is unreasonable that these vessels should be empowered to run in competition with our own vessels, I point out that it would be quite within the competency of their owners, if they thought fit, to start lines of ships betw'een the various ports of Australia. They could do so by fulfilling Australian conditions. That would be very much to the detriment of the Australian companies. These British shipping companies might say, " We are going to cut fares down to the lowest point, believing that this prohibition is imposed, to a large extent, against us for the advantage of your Australian shipping companies, which desire to exclude competition." In that case, whilst perhaps a few passengers would gain something, it would be at the expense of our own local marine. When one looks to the balance-sheets of the Australian companies, it is found that they are enjoying very satisfactory conditions. Indeed, they are prosperous, and are returning very good dividends to those who have invested money in their shares, notwithstanding the competition they have to face.
- That is the result of the combine.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - That may be so, but, at any rate, there is the fact that the running of the oversea vessels has not interfered with their prosperity.
- If the oversea companies started competing on our coasts, they would employ more Australian men.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - No; fewer Australian men would be employed if these ships were to be allowed to carry a few passengers between Australian ports.
- Let them man their ships on Australian conditions.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - But Australian conditions are very different from those under which the ships of these companies are usually worked. They have to be run in competition with the ships of foreign nations, and it is not within our power to make any provision as to how foreign companies shall man their ships. It is well known that British conditions are better in respect of pay, food', and accommodation than are the conditions prevailing on foreign vessels. It would be unreasonable for us to place difficulties in the way of the expansion of the British Mercantile Marine; for, while our own marine is of importance to us, it is a mere nothing as compared with the mercantile service of the British Empire. For many years we have made it our proud boast that the British Mercantile Marine is more numerous, and that its conditions are superior, to the mercantile marine of any other nation; and we ought not by our legislation to do anything to impair that British supremacy. We should rather liberalize our laws, so as to render every assistance we can to British ship-owners.
- Australian ships are British.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I should be sorry to think otherwise. By amending this clause as I have suggested, we Shall be doing great good.
- Why not strike out the proclamation part of it?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I do not suppose that the honorable senator would vote to strike out the clause altogether. Another matter of considerable importance relates to clause 372, which deals with the cancellation or the suspension of certificates. It is provided that if the certificate of any master or officer has been cancelled by a Court of Marine Inquiry in Australia, the fact that his certificate has been returned to him by the Board of Trade, or by the authority which originally granted it other than a Court of Appeal, shall not enable the master or officer to serve in Australia on board any ship in the capacity specified in the cancelled certificate. In the Merchant Shipping Act of 1904, provision is made for the cancellation of certificates, lt is here desired to differentiate between a case where a certificate has been cancelled by an authority within the Commonwealth arid a certificate which has been cancelled by the Board of Trade. Under the Merchant Shipping Act also, the Board of Trade may, if it think that the justice of the case requires it to be done, re-issue a certificate or shorten the time for which it has been suspended, or grant in lieu a certificate of the same or of a lower grade. Under clause 372, we take away, as far as Australia is concerned, the power contained in the Merchant Shipping Act, which is intended to be applicable to the whole of the British Dominions.
- Surely the honorable senator would not allow the Board of Trade, which is a Government Department, to override a Court presided over by a Judge? That is the point.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I take the position that we have limited powers, and ought to consider how far we are going to use them.
- Surely the honorable senator would not allow the Board of Trade to be a Court of Appeal from an Australian Court?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - In one of the despatches dealing with this Bill, there is a reference to the question. It is pointed out that the Merchant Shipping Act provides a speedy and simple remedy by allowing an appeal to a Government Department instead of to a higher Court.
- This is a procedure which the honorable senator would not adopt in connexion with any other legislation.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - From a despatch dated 18th September, 1908, I make this extract -

quote.para: With regard to the Board of Trade notes on clause 369 (now clause 372) of the Navigation Bill, your Ministers appear to have overlooked the fact that this clause purported to repeal, as regards Australia, a definite provision of the Mercantile Shipping Act of 1894, the application of which to Australia is beyond question, as the power there conferred upon the Board of Trade has been duly exercised at various times by the Board of Trade. Had a request been made by your Government that the Board of Trade should abandon the power which is thus conferred upon them by the Imperial Shipping Act it would have been a matter for the most careful consideration as to whether the power should or should not be retained. It will be seen from the memorandum by the Board of Trade, commenting on certain points in the Navigation Bill, a copy of which I enclose, that the hypothetical case put by your Government is not one which could conceivably occur, and that the power at present given to the Board of Trade is a useful authority in cases where certificates have been cancelled by Marine Boards.

talk.start.para: - We propose to do away with Marine Boards altogether.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I am aware of that. The despatch continues -

quote.para: In such cases your Ministers will no doubt agree that the Board of Trade is as convenient and as impartial an authority as could possibly be found. But no such application was made by your Ministers, nor was the matter discussed at the Merchant Shipping Conference, and as no reasons were given for the proposal, which His Majesty's Government are advised is certainly ultra vires, the Board of Trade could hardly be expected to reply to it further than by declining to concur in the proposals limiting their powers.

subdebate.1.para: The matter was again referred to in a cablegram from the Secretary of State, dated 27th November, 1903, from which I take the following -

quote.para: As regards clause 369 (now clause 372) His Majesty's Government have no doubt that the clause as it stands is ultra vires, in so far as it is not limited to coasting trade, and registered vessels, but they will consent, with reluctance, that in the case of Australia the powers given by the Imperial Act shall not be used, even with regard to vessels not registered nor coasting, thus avoiding the legal difficulties. lt was contemplated to meet the Board of Trade to a certain extent, and further correspondence passed in connexion with the matter. Then there was a cablegram to the following effect, dated 9th January,

Referring to my telegram dated 27th November, Navigation Bill, His Majesty's Government regret to state that on careful reconsideration of the whole question of the cancellation of certificate they have come to the conclusion that the method of dealing with the matter suggested in my telegram cannot legally be carried out. It would be improper that the Board of Trade should bind themselves in the matter of the exercise of the discretionary power expresslyconferred on them by section 474 of Merchant Shipping Act 1894. They, therefore, propose to accept clause 369 (now clause 372) of Navigation Bill as it stands in Bill as introduced into Senate, provided that in sub-clause 1, after the word " ship," the following words are inserted, namely, " registered in Australia or engaged in the coasting trade," and in sub-clause 2, after the word " serve," the following words, " upon any such ship as aforesaid." This agreement will concede substantially all that is desired by your late advisers, and is in harmony with the resolutions of the Navigation Conference, and I trust, therefore, that it will be acceptable to your present Government.

subdebate.1.para: Lord Crewe, writing to the GovernorGeneral subsequently, under date 12th February, 1909, says -

quote.para: In reply, I have to refer you to my telegram of the 9th January, from which it will be seen that His Majesty's Government regret that it is not possible to carry out precisely the arrangements contemplated in mv telegram of the 27th November last. I trust, 'however, that the compromise suggested in my telegram of the 9th January will commend itself to your Government as being in harmony with the resolutions of the Navigation Conference of 1907, and as conceding practically the whole measure of control desired by your Ministers.

subdebate.1.para: This correspondence shows how the Imperial authorities were willing to meet us in the matter. But, notwithstanding that, we still have clause 369, now clause 372, of the Bill before us in the objectionable form in which it was proposed in the first instance, providing -

quote.para: If the certificate of any master or officer, wherever issued, has been cancelled by a Court of Marine Inquiry in Australia, the fact that the certificate has been returned to him by the Board of Trade or the authority which originally granted the certificate, other than a Court of Appeal, shall not enable any such master or officer to serve in Australia on board any ship in the capacity specified in the certificate so cancelled.

subdebate.1.para: The Government are determined, apparently, to refuse to accept what, after all, I think is a reasonable suggestion on the part of the Imperial authorities. We should realize that our power is really con- fined to ships registered in the Commonwealth, or engaged in our coasting trade, and that the Imperial authorities desire to retain their powers under the Merchant Shipping Act. I think that the suggestion which has been made should appeal to honorable senators as a reasonable one. -If they will consult a paper tabled some time ago by the Commonwealth Government, they will find a fairly succinct account of the correspondence which has taken place between the Imperial and Commonwealth authorities in this connexion, and a statement of the way in which it has been dealt with.

talk.start.para: - Would the honorable senator be prepared, on any other question, to allow a Government Department to override the decision of a Court ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I think we should recognise that, although the Board of Trade may be described as a Government Department, it is composed of skilled persons who thoroughly understand the work they are called upon to perform. We have an assurance that their powers would not be unduly or unfairly exercised. I admit that, in nine cases out of ten, the decision of a Court having the advantage of listening to witnesses and noting their demeanour would be a correct decision on the merits of the case. But it should be remembered that the cancelled certificate would have been granted in the first instance by the Board of Trade, and accepted by us as evidence of the qualifications of the person to whom it was granted, and would not be reinstated by the Board of Trade unless upon evidence which it was felt would warrant them in taking that course.. Sooner than that there should be any trouble in connexion with a measure of this character, I think we should be prepared to accept the suggestion offered by the Imperial authorities. I think they have gone as far as we could expect in agreeing not to interfere in any matter connected with our coasting trade, or with ships registered in Australia.

- Take the case of the loss of the vessel off King Island the other day. Suppose, upon an inquiry into that wreck, a Court, consisting of a Judge and two assessors, decided to cancel the certificate of the master of the vessel, does the honorable senator contend that a Department of the Imperial Government should be allowed to step in and say that the Judge and assessors of the Court in

subdebate.1.para: Australia were wrong, and return his certificate to the master?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I reply in this way : The Court could, no doubt, cancel the certificate on the evidence before it; but the Board of Trade, as the body granting the certificate in the first instance, are concerned to see that every care is observed, by the master in charge of a ship, and would take all the evidence into consideration before attempting to interfere with any decision of the Court. . If I thought that the Board of Trade would interfere in such a matter lightly, and without full consideration, I should object to their dealing with a matter of the kind.
- The honorable senator does not know whether they would do so or not.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I do not believe that men placed in such a position would attempt to override the decision of a Court, unless they were thoroughly satisfied, for sufficient reason, that a more lenient view might be taken. A case occurs to ' me at this moment of a master of a vessel who was trading along our coast for practically a life-time. He had the misfortune to lose his ship, and on the finding of the- Court of Inquiry he lost his certificate. In spite of ' this fact the greatest public sympathy was extended to him, because it was admitted that he had invariably exercised the utmost care for the safety of his passengers and ship. In such a case, and unless the evidence showed that the master was guilty of gross carelessness, I think it would not be unreasonable to give him back his certificate. I know that I should be glad if there were a body empowered' to review a case of the kind. I believe that the Court that dealt with the certificate of the master to whom I have referred would have welcomed such an opportunity for a review of the matter. I have addressed myself to provisions of the Bill which appear to. me to call for' some observations on the second reading. It is possible that I ' may have omitted reference to provisions of equal importance; but I know that we shall have an opportunity of dealing with the Bill in detail in Committee, assuming that we remain in session sufficiently long to enable us to do so. I do not know whether, as on previous occasions, this Bill will be taken up to fill in time when there is nothing else before us.
- No; we are in deadly earnest this time.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I am reminded by the course followed in connexion with similar measures in previous sessions, of the round of cold corned beef on the sideboard, at which people can cut and come again when there is nothing else in the house. ' It is well to know that there is a good round of corned beef to fall back upon. In introducing this Bill the Minister said -

quote.para: The first important feature of the measure is that it docs not apply to ships of His Majesty:i Navy, and in this respect follows the Merchant Shipping Act, and the New Zealand Act.

subdebate.1.para: When he made that statement I could net help recollecting that we have no power to deal with the ships of His Majesty's Navy, so that they might well say to the Government, " Thank you for nothing." I shall approach the consideration of the Bill in Committee with a desire to make it as reasonably effective as possible. I wish to see a seafaring life made as attractive as possible to our own people, and, at the same time, to insure the protection of those who are interested in having their goods carried to market at reasonable freights and under fair conditions. I note that under this measure the punishments provided for offences have been materially lessened, as compared with the punishments which are provided ' for similar offences under the Imperial Act, and an attempt has been made to define " desertion " more strictly than it was previously defined.

talk.start.para: - In' Great Britain punishment for desertion has been abolished.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - That is so. The. Bill provides that- "Desertion" means the absence of a seaman or apprentice from his ship without lawful cause or excuse, with .the intention of not returning thereto.

subdebate.1.para: The words " with the intention of not returning thereto " have been added .to this definition since the measure was last before this Chamber. Consequently, in order to prove desertion, it will be necessary for the master of a vessel to show not only that a' seaman has left his ship without lawful cause or excuse, but, also, that he has left it with the intention of not returning thereto.

talk.start.para: - Has not that always been the law?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - No. If the honorable senator will read up the law on the subject, he will find that the words " with the intention of not returning, thereto " are absent. It is true that the Court has always taken that aspect of the question into its consideration. But under this definition a man may quit his ship, leaving behind him a number of small articles which are not worth taking away; and, in such circumstances, it will be extremely difficult to prove desertion against him. Amongst other anomalies in the Bill, honorable senators will find one relating to assault. The Bill provides that if a seaman assaults an officer, he shall be liable to three months imprisonment; but that if an officer assaults a seaman, he shall be liable to six months' imprisonment. Why it should be a more serious offence for an officer to assault a seaman than for a seaman to assault an officer, I do not know.
- Because the officer should have more sense.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: .-That may be so. In dealing with the Bill, 1 hope that we shall have these difficulties fully before us, so that we may not enact legislation which it will be difficult to accept on the other side of the world. We ought to show, as far as we possibly can, that we are in thorough sympathy with the ' British mercantile marine, and that we do not desire to place disadvantages upon those who are engaged in its service ; always realizing that our strength is largely dependent upon the strength of the Empire on the deep seas and blue waters.

subdebate.1.para: Debate (on motion by Senator Millen) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator McGregor) proposed -

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: .- Will the Vice-President of the Executive Council inform me whether it is the intention of the Government to proceed first with the consideration of the Bank Note Tax Bill on Tuesday next?
- It is.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - Will the debate on the Navigation Bill be resumed afterwards, or will some other measure be dealt with?
- When the Bank Notes Tax Bill has been dealt with we shall proceed withthe debate on the Navigation Bill.
